The Story-Everything except the few times mentioned above with Joel\, the story feels forced and unnatural.-The characters that we grew to love in the first game\, make out-of-character decisions in order to move along whatever story they’re wanting to express\, which is basically just a circle of violence and vengeance that is boring and predictable.-This story has a strong political motivation\, trying to shoehorn in LGBTQ+ agendas\, as well as new age feminism\, forcing us into unrealistic decision making that goes against the gritty realism we’ve come to expect from its predecessor.-The acting\, taken out of context of the character and his/her development is good\, even great at points\, but when you insert the context of the story\, it makes you want to either roll your eyes in mockery or scream from frustration\, to the point that you actually want the character you’re playing to fail and die.2.) Gameplay-If you enjoyed the first game’s gameplay\, then you ought to enjoy this one too\, because they’re very close to the same with a little bit extra to keep it interesting. However\, it’s not nearly enough for the 25+ hour game time filled with mostly cutscenes\, exploring\, and fighting various baddies. They’ve mostly done away with puzzles\, of which I found novel in the first game\, and replaced it with anemic exploration. And the puzzles that they do have are painstakingly obvious\, to the point where the only difficult ‘puzzle’ is finding the exit.-Crafting has become slightly more complex\, and with the increased options in advancing your skill set via supplements\, you can experience a slightly altered version of Ellie and *unnamed* character\, but it feels stale\, adding very little newness.-Everything else is practically the same.
